reviewText: Loved it! Really makes you think about the people in your life; living or deceased. Very well done, not too overly holiday sweet.
In the beginning we didn't know what we had gotten into. I almost turned it off. It is definitely not one of those predictable Christmas stories! But it was amazing.
One of those good "under the radar" films. Definitely worth the $2.99 rental. Uplifting, but not sugar coated. Stay with it to the end.
Kind of weird!!!!
Wonderful movie. A unique concept that worked beautifully.

A heartwarming story told in an unusual way. Thought provoking and moving this film has become a 'must see' in our house at Christmas.
Highly recommended!

Lost Christmas is a story with big heart.  It is a magical, ethereal, modern day tale of morality which engages, delights and inspires.
As the plot unfolds there is something for everyone, and with a sterling British cast is deliverers throughout, which makes it the perfect blend for family viewing.

Highly recommended.
The perfect Christmas film to fill your heart with Christmas magic. Filled with love, heartbreak, redemption and even a little comedy. A Christmas classic to rival It's a Wonderful Life.
Very boring!

A pleasant surprise that went well beyond my expectations. If you're like me you probably enjoy the Christmas classics but you also get tired of sitting through the same movies with family and friends year-after-year over-and-over. That said, it can be difficult to find christmas themed films that are less known but worth watching. Most are terribly-cheesy, low budget unoriginal love stories or so childish it makes anyone beyond the age of 12 cringe. In my mind, Lost Christmas does enough to escape the pitfalls mentioned above and has a very different look and feel than most christmas films.  It grabs you early and draws you closer as the story unfolds into a warm holiday message. Surprisingly this film has been out since 2014. Hopefully you enjoy it as much as I did :)
It is hard to understand at the beginning; however, the ending of the movie is great. Sometimes, a small thing can change everything.
Wow! This movie and the moral behind it is amazing. It even had my 9 year old daughter in tears at the end. It may be a little confusing at first but watch until the end and you won't regret it.
Forget Christmas.  Here we've got Shiva and karma and salvation by good deeds.  Name your own holidays, leave Christmas alone.
I really liked this movie. It wasn't told from the normal Christmas story perspective - I liked that it was different.

If you are used to the usual, predictable common girl meets her prince story that is recycled every year and passed off as a Christmas story, it's time to break out of the rot and experience a Christmas movie that raises the bar to heights of excellence. The story is brilliant! I actually gave it a standing ovation in my room.
Not your ordinary Christmas Show..  Don't give up early..  The end is worth it

A beautiful and poignant story of a young boy who loses his family on Christmas Eve. The story takes places one year later and shows the hardships that he has had to endure. It also shows how each live we touch is interconnected in ways we didn't even realize existed. I cried during several parts but was rewarded at the end with a story of self-sacrifice, redemption, and love. It's not for young children as the themes may be difficult to handle but for pre-teens and up, yes. It makes for excellent discussion with your children as to how doing the right thing isn't always easy. I read the reviews after watching and was appalled at the ignorance of others claiming it was difficult to understand due to the language. Keep in mind the accents are British and if you're that narrow minded you could always have put on the subtitles. The story itself was heartwarming and enduring though at times, depressing as heck, but the ending made it worth the tears. The cover shouldn't have a young boy and his dog on there as it alludes to a different type of Christmas story and is misleading, but if you're in the mood for a movie that is thought provoking and moving, this is it; though, keep a box of tissue handy. If you love redemptive stories such as Charles Dickens "A Christmas Carol" or "It's a Wonderful Life", then you can probably handle the theme throughout this story. Yes, at times, it's confusing with the varying stories, but if you stick with it all the through, it makes such perfect sense in its final reveal. I will watch this one again and again.
plot twist ! nice and cool

Somewhat bizarre scenes in the beginning.  We stopped this movie after 15 minutes of watching it.  Not what we expected at all.  Maybe the story line would have gotten better later; but we lost patience.

This is not your typical Christmas fairy tale. It rests on the interrelatedness of things, including the lives of people. Event A brings about event B--especially if mysterious Mr. Anthony facilitates the process. Not just "fluff" - substance. Not what I expected. Eerie, interesting and real. My tween was complaining, "Not another Christmas movie!". I chose this one and she was completely into it. It was a reality check for her to get her outside her suburban bubble of humanity where nothing is good enough. USE THE CAPTIONS or you will miss some of the dialogue. Nothing is "inappropriate" for kids (except maybe the alcoholic behavior)- this is portrayed in a real sense without any gruesomeness, the movie ultimately shows how he ended up there.

This is probably the darkest Christmas story since Dickens. It starts out as a cheery Christmas Eve when Richard gets a puppy. An hour later both his parents are killed in a car crash. A year later, Richard's life is a mess. He's living with his grandmother who has dementia, he's become a pickpocket and has to pay weekly visits to his probation officer. When his dog goes missing, a very creepy stranger shows up to help Richard get his life back together. Along the way, other people become part of Richard's day, people who have lost something dear to them. It's a puzzle begging to be solved, and comedian Eddie Izzard is marvelous as the mysterious stranger who brings peace on Christmas Eve.

This Christmas story lightened my heart.  2016 has been one of the more miserable years I can remember in 63 years.  I never imagined America would put a psychopathic masochist in the White House.  Truly wish there was magic that could erase bigotry, hatred of others, bring the true meaning of Christmas: LOVE.  I am frightened of the next four years.  I believe America will loose many of its best and brightest minds to other countries.  I pray that someone some where will stand up against tbe heresy that has been forced upon us all because 49% of America failed to vote.  I will pray for the type of personality change that happened in this movie, just by being honest about the smallest things in one's life can have a major effect on us all.

The most loving story that is kind and soft with an unexpected story line THAT WILL BRING TEARS TO UR EYES, BOTH OF HAPPINESS and sorrow.  That LOVE and COMPASSION  should always b a part of our lives, because we've not walked in the other person's shoes.

For the sake of those who treasure Christmas and it's meaning, I have to warn that this movie is not what you are looking for. I felt it had very little to do with Christmas, especially for those who are Christ followers. Even for people who are looking for a secular Christmas movie , this is still not it. This is filled with eastern mysticism, clairvoyance, and false teachings that Christians will find offensive to good doctrine. The story itself was slow moving, but is all cleared up in the end. I really can't believe I watched it to the end. I think I kept hoping for a redemptive quality. Acting was fine. All in all, it just did not have the Christmasy feel. I almost want it to be titled something different.

However, he gets a chance to correct his mistake and we see what the boy chooses to do with this opportunity.

We got about 15 minutes into the movie and both agreed that it was abruptly sad and continued to be, very slow and why on earth did that man have his underwear on and walked outside.  He was inappropriately close to the boy during that scene as well.  Now I wonder if it wasn't rated as it was advertised as a family movie, but couldn't qualify for a G or PG rating.  Very disappointed.

If you do not like this movie then Bah Humbug to you! The movie does take some time to develop but if you stick with it until the end you will be greatly rewarded. Do not let the cute pup and boy on the cover make you think it is a kids flick. It is for all ages and a story of redemption.  Eddie Izzard plays a wonderful role. To all of you out there who gave it a bad review - really? You probably hated It's A Wonderful Life also and deserve lumps of coal in your stocking.

It is not your traditional Christian/Christmas movie.  It is not filled with Christmas trees, Santa, etc.  If you are expecting a movie like this, you will probably be disappointed.  It does start a bit slow and there are British themes/nuances which may be a bit difficult to follow.  I was definitely expecting something different.  However, our family really enjoyed it as it is quite touching and highlights values of redemption, forgiveness, kindness and love.
Simply brilliant! This just made it to the top of my must watch every Christmas list!

This movie exceeded my expectations 10 fold. It takes a little while to understand what's going on, but keep going! This movie is probably not the best choice for kids under the age of 9 and there are sad moments, but it's so uplifting and I was definitely shedding a few tears towards the end. The acting is great and I can't wait to watch this again!

When I first started watching this, it was extremely depressing. Not even in a quirky way, just in a really depressing way. About 25 minutes in, I went back to look at the reviews, and people said stick with it, so I did.

First of all, this is not a "family" Christmas movie. I think teenagers could see it and some older kids. Second the movie is quite sad and many upsetting things happen. However, this is necessary for the ending to work.

The movie is about how several people's lives are intertwined by a tragic event that happened one Christmas Eve. This sends most of them on a downward spiral until until the next Christmas Eve, when a mysterious amnesiac man shows up and starts bringing them together.

Well, it's hard to explain. See it yourself if you're looking for something more serious than the typical holiday film.
Heartbreaking, touching and uplifting all in the same movie.  Should become a Christmas classic.  I could watch it over and over.

I wanted to watch this  before my kids to make sure it was appropriate for them. ( I'm also a fan of Eddie Izzard)  I've decided that this isn't appropriate for my family.  Firstly it's a little dark.  It has a happy ending, and all that is broken is mended in the end, but it is a "Christmas" movie that has nothing to do with Christianity.  There is a cobra bracelet that is central to the movie's plot, and  representative of a Hindu deity.  It is the cobra deity who, as a character explains, destroys things in order to make them new.  It's not a bad movie, plot-wise.  The acting is fine in my opinion.  The characters exhibit many good qualities and values. If you are a totally secular person you'll probably like this, but if you are a Christian looking for a Christmas movie, just pass.  It's a Wonderful Life, it ain't!
It may be hard to get into but stick with it. Those giving it bad reviews turned it off before the wonderful surprise ending. This is now one of my favorite Christmas movies of all time.

While I can understand how some people may think it a little grim at times, I thought this film a rare find. Not a sappy TV Christmas film, but filled with the grit of real life. The idiom is very Brit and may take an adjustment, but it's well worth the effort.
A little boy his his dad's car keys on Christmas Eve, hoping to keep him home from work, setting in motion a chain of tragedies. One year later, an unusual bloke shows up and...well, I wouldn't want to ruin it. Those who watch PBS and Masterpiece will see some familiar faces. An intelligent, challenging Christmas mystery with a slightly supernatural twist. I think Mr. Dickens would be pleased to have it join his "Ghostly little book" in the holiday canon.
I love this movie.  I have watched t three times.  It is right up there with all the Christmas movies.  Do not miss this one.

This movie was interesting sort of It's a wonderful life.
It does have a happy ending sadly we wish we could do things all over again.
And making things right again but not through magic or anything else.
But through Jesus Christ who died for our sins and not in Satan's grip which lives he destroys.
But through Jesus Christ who makes all things new again and we find we can forgive ourselves and others.
There is ONE who already give his life and no need to sacrifice our lives to make things right again.
And crying may endure through the night but JOY comes in the morning. And we find PEACE &  JOY again.
And lost souls can be restored again not just at Christmas time but all year long.
Would I ask others to see this movie most likely not but say for others to see it for themselves.
And decide for themselves.

A potential classic, on par with It's A Wonderful Life ... except this has a couple of twists.
Last Christmas Eve was a scene of horror in Manchester, UK.  Tragedies occurred left and right, starting with ten-year-old 'Goose' (Larry Mills) becoming an orphan.  A year later Goose is still living with his increasingly dotty Granny (Sorcha Cusack), and developing into quite the little sneak thief.  His closest friend is Frank (Jason Flemyng), one of his dad's co-workers whose own life in now in a downward spiral.  Into this scene comes Anthony (Eddie Izzard), an amnesiac with most remarkable sleight of hand skills and an amazing ability - when he touches someone's hand he has a vision of how they lost something precious - and even what happened to the lost item when that person wasn't around,  Bit by bit lost objects are found and restored to their rightful owners.  And only when all mysteries are solved do we find out who Anthony is, and how Goose can get back his lost dog and so much more. (Tedious note: a subplot invents a completely fictitious bibliographic history for Oscar Wilde's The Happy Prince).  Not for kiddies but immensely satisfying for adults. Runs 90 minutes, originally a British TV movie.

I highly recommend it!

How can anyone give this movie anything less than five stars? This movie hit all the right holiday movie nerves. Uplifting, sad, sweet you name it and the emotion is here. Larry Mills as the young man of the film is outstanding. he has all of the right nuances down pat. Eddie Izzard is terrific and so is Jason Flemyng. As a matter of fact there is not one weak performance to be found anywhere on this screen. it is a story of loss and lost things, it is about redemption no matter what your age. There is a magical quality about it that I think only the British could have given it.

Not for everyone... it has a kind of dark feel, but I found it very pleasant.  Quite a surprise find for me:  I caught the tail end of it on cable, and was intrigued enough to purchase.  Definitely different!

While others raved about this film, I did not like its convoluted spirituality mixing Christian mysticism and Hindu reincarnation and 2nd chances. It makes a travesty of the Christian message that Jesus Christ is the only way to God and that "No one comes to the Father except through Him".  However, it deals with the the results of choices humans and angels make ( is the Juggler Lucifer, the angel of light?) and how we often do not see the long-termed implications of choices made in the confines of a moment. God's grace is unmerited but costly, costing God His very precious Son. When all seems lost because of selfish choices, grace and mercy come running to us, with arms open wide as in the story of the Prodigal Son, with the Father ever looking for his son and not resting until he returns home and then restoration and celebration enjoins in one beautiful symphony.  Don't waste your time seeing this movie, but rather spend it reading the Word of God in 2015, asking God to give you opportunities to share His love with others.

Charming, sentimental Christmas story about loss, redemption and second chances.  Cast is outstanding.  Get the tissues ready--you will need them.  I saw part of this on cable and had to get my own copy.

When we look back, we often see other paths we could have taken, other possibilities. The ways we choose, the choices we make and sometimes believe are made for us, against our will, decide the road we continue along. Quantum physics says that every possibility that can happen DOES happen. Does that mean that we can alter the reality we are in now, in hindsight,  to the way we would want things to be? This story asks, and maybe answers, that question.

Despite the title, I personally think this transcends  any particular man made season. It speaks to the heart, and the soul. I gave it to others before even watching it myself. Upon watching it, I will be giving it to a few more people in my life. Peace, love and bright blessings.

So good I want to watch it again right now! Eddie Izzard was brilliant in this. All the acting was superb. So very touching and sweet. You will find yourself laughing at moments you would think call for tears, and being moved to tears during moments that other movies might make a joke about. This movie explores the concept of actions and the impact we have on those around us. It encourages hope and faith and making unselfish choices. Do not be discouraged by negative reviews, this is a beautiful story in the vain of  'A Christmas Carol' or 'It's a Wonderful Life'. Yes, it is certainly tongue in cheek with regards to religion, - WARNING SPOILER to FOLLOW: (Shiva Statue decked out with Christmas lights) so if you are easily offended and humorless...don't bother.
